title: Primary culture of immature, naïve mouse CD4+ T cells
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Neonatal mouse spleen isolation and single splenocyte suspension preparation
Timing: 45–55 min
This step contains information on how to isolate the mouse spleen and how to prepare single splenocyte suspension.
Euthanize P21 mice by CO2 inhalation.
Lay a mouse on its back on a dissection mat, pin the paws on the mat, and spray with 70% ethanol to wet the fur.
Make an incision in the peritoneum and cut the inferior vena cava to bleed the mouse to reduce the red blood cells left in the spleen.
Gently lift the spleen by a pair of forceps and remove the attached pancreatic tissue with scissors. Transfer the spleen to a 15 mL collection tube containing 5 mL of T cell culture medium (Table 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl3]) with forceps.
Pour the spleen with T cell culture medium into a 100 mm Petri dish.
Critical: To maintain the aseptic condition, work in the tissue culture hood.
Put a 70 μm cell strainer on top of a 50 mL conical tube and rinse the cell strainer with 1 mL ice cold 1×PBS (pH 7.4).
Smash the spleen on the cell strainer using a sterile plunger of a 1 mL syringe and flush the cell strainer with 10 mL ice cold 1×PBS (pH7.4).
Discard the cell strainer and centrifuge the sample at 400 × g for 15 min at 4°C.
Discard the supernatant by gently flipping the 50 mL tube. Add 2 mL red blood cell lysis buffer to the tube and resuspend the splenocytes by gentle pipetting. Incubate for 3 min on ice.
Note: Optimal lysis of erythrocytes is usually achieved by incubating at room temperature. However, for subsequent naive CD4+ T cell purification, the manufacturer suggests that cells always be kept cold. So, we keep the cells on ice.

Add 5 mL of T cell culture medium to stop the lysis of red blood cells and centrifuge the sample at 400 × g for 5 min at 4°C.
Discard the supernatant. Resuspend the splenocytes with 10 mL of ice cold pH 7.4 1×PBS and keep the cells on ice until finishing the cell counting.
Note: Repeat step 9–10 if the cell pellet is still red.
Take out 20 μL of the cell suspension, dilute 10 times in 0.1% trypan blue, and determine the splenocyte number with hemocytometer.
Take 7 × 106 splenocytes prior to naïve CD4+ T cell purification for staining of the compensation control and for the evaluation of naive CD4+ T cells percentage before purification by flow cytometry.
Neonatal naïve CD4+ T-cell purification via magnetic bead-based negative selection
Timing: 25–30 min
This step contains information on how to purify naïve CD4+ T cells from the splenocyte suspension using a magnetic bead-based isolation kit. More information about this procedure can be found on manufacturer’s website: https://www.miltenyibiotec.com/US-en/products/naive-cd4-t-cell-isolation-kit-mouse.html#gref[href=https://www.miltenyibiotec.com/US-en/products/naive-cd4-t-cell-isolation-kit-mouse.html%23gref]
Centrifuge the sample at 400 × g for 5 min at 4°C and discard the supernatant completely.
Resuspend the cell pellet in 400 μL of purification buffer (Table 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl1]) per 10⁸ total cells and then add 100 μL of Biotin-Antibody Cocktail per 10⁸ total cells. Mix well and incubate for 5 min in the refrigerator (2–8°C).
table:files/protocols_protocol_936_1.csv
Sterilize with 0.22 μm filter and store at 4°C for up to 1 month.
Add 200 μL of purification buffer, 200 μL of Anti-Biotin MicroBeads and 100 μL of CD44 MicroBeads per 10⁸ total cells in sequence. Mix them well and incubate for 10 min in the refrigerator (2–8°C).
Place a LS column in the magnetic field of MidiMACS Separator and prepare the LS column by rinsing with 3 mL of purification buffer.

Apply the cell suspension onto the column and collect the flow-through that contain unlabeled cells enriched in naïve CD4+ T cells.
Wash the column with 3 mL of purification buffer. Collect unlabeled cells in the flow-through and combine with the flow-through from step 18.
Determine the cell number with hemocytometer. Take 1 × 106 cells for staining to evaluate the purity of naïve CD4+ T cells by flow cytometry.
Alternatives: Here, we used the magnetic bead-based negative selection isolation kit to purify naïve CD4+ T cells because it is effective and time saving. Magnetic bead-based positive selection isolation kit can also be used for purification. Another alternative approach is to FACS-sort naïve CD4+ T cells that yields slightly higher purity; however, it takes longer time and requires a cell sorter. As few as 0.2 million cells can be used for staining to evaluate the purity.
Evaluate naïve CD4+ T-cell purity by flow cytometry
Timing: 2 h
This step contains information on antibody staining to evaluate the purity of the isolated naïve CD4+ T cells by flow cytometry. In total, 7 × 106 splenocytes (before purification) and 1 × 106 purified naïve CD4+ T cells will be used. Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1] shows the allocation of these cells for different staining in a 96-well plate.
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/936-Fig1.jpg
Figure 1. Layout of a 96-well round bottom plate setup for the staining of compensation controls, splenocytes and naïve CD4+ T cells after enrichment
Take 1 × 106 splenocytes and fix them with 4% PFA for 10 min on ice to generate a positive control for dead cell staining.
Wash twice of the fixed cells by adding 300 μL of FACS buffer (Table 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl2]). Centrifuge at 400 × g for 5 min at 4°C to collect the cell pellet.
table:files/protocols_protocol_936_2.csv

Store at 4°C for up to 1 month.
Mix fixed cells with 1 × 106 unfixed splenocytes and use this sample as a single-stained cell compensation control for Fixable Viability Dye.
Transfer 1 × 106 unfixed cells to each allocated well of a 96-well round bottom plate and centrifuge the plate at 400 × g for 5 min at 4°C. Discard the supernatant completely.
Critical: During the following steps, cells have to be protected from light with aluminum foil.
During the spin, prepare Live/Dead Fixable Viability Dye eFluor 780 staining solution by diluting 1 μL of a concentrated stock with 2 mL of 1×PBS (pH 7.4).
Resuspend the cell pellet in one well as the compensation control for Fixable Viability Dye staining and the two wells for multiple staining with 100 μL of diluted Live/Dead Fixable Viability Dye eFluor 780. Resuspend the cell pellet in other wells with 200 μL 1×PBS (pH 7.4) and incubate for 30 min at 4°C.
During the incubation, prepare multiple staining antibody solution as shown in Table 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl4] and single staining solutions.
table:files/protocols_protocol_936_3.csv
Store at 4°C for up to 1 month.
table:files/protocols_protocol_936_4.csv
Prepare immediately before use.
Centrifuge the plate at 400 × g for 5 min at 4°C and discard the supernatant. Wash the cell pellet twice using 300 μL of FACS buffer.
Resuspend the cell pellet in the two wells for multiple staining with 100 μL of antibody mix 1 solution and cell pellets in other wells for single staining with 100 μL of respective single staining solution. Resuspend the cell pellet in the well for Fixable Viability Dye staining with 100 μL of FACS buffer. Incubate for 30 min at 4°C.

Note: According to the manufacturer’s protocol, it is best to stain with Live/Dead Fixable Viability Dye in azide and protein-free PBS for the brightest staining.
Wash twice by adding 300 μL of FACS buffer, centrifuge the plate at 400 × g for 5 min at 4°C, and discard the supernatant.
Resuspend the cell pellet in 300 μL of FACS buffer. Passage the cell suspension through the 40 μm cell strainer on top of the 5 mL Falcon® tube before analysis with Fortessa 405/488/561/640 (BD Biosciences) flow cytometer.
See Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2] for the gating strategy of naïve CD4+ T cell analysis with Flowjo software. Purity over 95% is considered acceptable. If the purity is less than 95%, another round of enrichment is suggested.
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/936-Fig2.jpg
Figure 2. Gating strategy used to evaluate the purity of naïve CD4+ T cells before and after enrichment
(A) Representative result of naïve CD4+ T cells purity within splenocytes from C57BL/6J mouse at P21.
(B) Representative result of naïve CD4+ T cells purity after enrichment.
Alternatives: OneComp eBeads™ (01-1111-42, Invitrogen) can also be used for compensation purposes. A mouse, rat or hamster origin antibody with APC-Cy7 labeling should be used for the compensation of Fixable Viability Dye eFluor 780.
Critical: Since some surface markers, like CD62L, are temperature sensitive, always keep the plate on ice during the process of staining and use a centrifuge setting at 4°C.
Neonatal naïve CD4+ T-cell differentiation in vitro
Timing: 4 days
This step contains information on differentiation conditions of neonatal naïve CD4+ T cells.
Centrifuge the purified naïve CD4+ T cells at 400 × g for 5 min at 4°C and discard the supernatant completely.
During the spin, wash the αCD3 pre-coated, 48-well tissue culture plate with 1mL 1×PBS (pH 7.4).

Resuspend the cell pellet with T cell culture medium (Table 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl3]) and adjust the cell density to 1 × 106 cells/mL.
Seed 5 × 105 cells in 0.5 mL cell suspension in each well of the 48-well tissue culture plate.
For Th0, Th1, Th2 and Th17 cultures, add respective antibodies, chemicals and recombinant proteins following the instructions in Tables 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl5], 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl6], 7[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl7], and 8[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl8].
table:files/protocols_protocol_936_5.csv
table:files/protocols_protocol_936_6.csv
table:files/protocols_protocol_936_7.csv
table:files/protocols_protocol_936_8.csv
Note: Prepare immediately before use and add the reagents individually to the culture medium. As human IL-2 stimulates proliferation of mouse T cells at similar concentration, we used human IL-2 in our protocol. Alternatively, mouse IL-2 can also be used at the same concentration.
Note: Prepare immediately before use and add reagents individually to the culture medium. As human IL-2 stimulates proliferation of mouse T cells at similar concentration, we used human IL-2 in our protocol. Alternatively, mouse IL-2 can also be used at the same concentration.
Note: Prepare immediately before use and add reagents individually to the culture medium. As human IL-2 stimulates proliferation of mouse T cells at similar concentration, we used human IL-2 in our protocol. Alternatively, mouse IL-2 can also be used at the same concentration.

Note: Prepare immediately before use and add reagents individually to the culture medium. As human IL-2 stimulates proliferation of mouse T cells at similar concentration, we used human IL-2 in our protocol. Alternatively, mouse IL-2 can also be used at the same concentration. The optimal working concentration of TGF-β should be titrated by the operator, since it can vary among different batches. As naive CD4+ T cells do not express IL-23R and IL-23 promotes maintenance but not commitment to the Th17 lineage (Stritesky et al., 2008[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib11]), add IL-23 after 2 days. Only adding the 5μL of IL-23 to each well with the already existing culture medium containing the other reconbimants/reagents.
Note: Add IL-23 after 2 days.
Put the plate into a CO2 incubator and culture for 4 days at 37°C with 5% CO2.
Alternatives: we have employed a suboptimal differentiation condition in our screen for neurotransmitters that can modulate CD4+ T cell differentiation. Standard T cell differentiation can be achieved by adding anti-mIL-4 antibody (10 μg/mL) to Th1 culture, anti-mIFN-γ antibody (10 μg/mL) to Th2 culture, anti-mIL-4 antibody (10 μg/mL) and anti-mIFN-γ antibody (10 μg/mL) to Th17 culture at the beginning of each culture.
Evaluate T-cell differentiation by cytokine gene expression assays via qPCR
Timing: 3.5–4 h
This step contains information on RNA extraction and quantification of cytokine gene expression by qPCR to evaluate T cell differentiation.
RNA extraction. More information about RNA extraction can be found on manufacturer’s website: https://www.qiagen.com/us/resources/resourcedetail?id=14e7cf6e-521a-4cf7-8cbc-bf9f6fa33e24&lang=en[href=https://www.qiagen.com/us/resources/resourcedetail?id=14e7cf6e-521a-4cf7-8cbc-bf9f6fa33e24&lang=en]
Determine the cell number at the end of T cell culture. Collect cells (no more than 5 × 106 cells) in a 1.5 mL centrifuge tube by spinning for 5 min at 400 × g. Carefully discard all the supernatant.

Note: Incomplete removal of the supernatant will inhibit lysis and dilute the lysate. These factors may reduce the RNA yield.
Pause point: Proceed with RNA extraction following manufacturer’s protocol or snap freeze the cell pellet in liquid nitrogen before storage at −80°C.
Flick the tube to thoroughly loosen the cell pellet and add 350 μL Buffer RLT. Mix well by pipetting.
Transfer the lysate into a QIAshredder spin column placed in a 2 mL collection tube and centrifuge for 2 min at 8000 × g.
Add 1 volume of 70% ethanol to the homogenized lysate, and pipet up and down to mix well.
Critical: Do not centrifuge.
Transfer up to 700 μL of the sample to an RNeasy spin column placed in a 2 mL collection tube. Centrifuge for 15 s at 8000 × g. Discard the flow-through.
Optional: If performing optional on-column DNase digestion to eliminating genomic DNA contamination, follow Appendix D in manufacturer’s protocol after performing this step.
Add 700 μL Buffer RW1 to the column and centrifuge for 15 s at 8000 × g to wash the column. Discard the flow-through.
Add 500 μL Buffer RPE to the column and centrifuge for 15 s at 8000 × g to wash the column. Discard the flow-through.
Add 500 μL Buffer RPE to the column and centrifuge for 2 min at 8000 × g to wash the column.
Optional: Place the column into a new 2 mL collection tube and centrifuge at 8000 × g for 1 min to completely remove Buffer RPE.
Place the RNeasy spin column into a new 1.5 mL collection tube. Add 30 μL RNase-free water to the spin column membrane and centrifuge for 1 min at 8000 × g to elute the RNA.

First-strand cDNA synthesis. More information about the first-strand cDNA synthesis procedure can be found on manufacturer’s website: https://assets.thermofisher.com/TFS-Assets/LSG/manuals/superscriptIII_man.pdf[href=https://assets.thermofisher.com/TFS-Assets/LSG/manuals/superscriptIII_man.pdf]
Determine the RNA concentration of each sample by NanoDrop™ 2000 spectrophotometer.
Follow Table 9[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl9] to make the mix for step 1.
table:files/protocols_protocol_936_9.csv
Note: According to the manufactory’s protocol, the amount of starting material can vary from 1 pg–5 μg of total RNA. In our protocol, we used 1 μg of total RNA.
Add the above components to a nuclease-free microcentrifuge tube. Heat mixture to 65°C for 5 min and incubate on ice for at least 1 min.
During the incubation, follow Table 10[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl10] to prepare the mix for step 2.
table:files/protocols_protocol_936_10.csv
Collect the contents of the tubes by brief centrifugation and add cDNA mix 2 to the tubes.
Mix by gently pipetting up and down and incubate at 50°C for 50 min.
Inactivate the reaction by heating at 85°C for 5 min and hold at 4°C.
PCR reaction. More information about PCR reaction procedure can be found on manufacturer’s website: https://assets.thermofisher.com/TFS-Assets/LSG/manuals/cms_042252.pdf[href=https://assets.thermofisher.com/TFS-Assets/LSG/manuals/cms_042252.pdf]
Dilute the cDNA template to 10 ng/μL with distilled water.
Follow Table 11[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl11] to make the mix for PCR reaction. Mix TaqMan® PCR Master Mix with different TaqMan® primers first and transfer them to a 96 well Unskirted qPCR Plate. Add diluted cDNA templates to respective wells.
table:files/protocols_protocol_936_11.csv
Cover the qPCR plate with optical flat 8-cap strips and centrifuge at 600 × g for 1 min.
Follow Table 12[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl12] to set up the PCR program in a real-time PCR machine.
table:files/protocols_protocol_936_12.csv
See Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4] for representative relative expression levels of Il13, Ifng, and Il17 in CD4+ T cells after differentiation for 4 days.
Alternatives: Here we used two-step RT-PCR. Alternatively, a one-step RT-PCR assay may be used to save time and reagent cost.

Evaluate T-cell differentiation by cytokine expression assays via flow cytometry
Timing: 7–7.5 h
This step contains information on fixation, permeabilization, antibody staining for different cytokines in differentiated CD4+ T cells by flow cytometry.
Cell stimulation
Dilute the 500× Cell Stimulation Cocktail (plus protein transport inhibitors) in the cultures to 1×.
Put the cultures back to CO2 incubator and incubate for 4 h.
Collect the cells by centrifuge at 400 × g for 5 min at 4°C and discard the supernatant.
Resuspend the cell pellet in 300 μL of FACS buffer and transfer to each allocated well of a 96-well round bottom plate and centrifuge the plate at 400 × g for 5 min at 4°C. Discard the supernatant completely.
Live/Dead cell staining and surface marker staining
During the spin, prepare Live/Dead Fixable Viability Dye eFluor 780 staining solution by diluting 1 μL of original solution with 2 mL of 1×PBS (pH 7.4).
Note: During the following steps, cells have to be protected from light.
Resuspend the cell pellet with 100 μL of diluted Live/Dead Fixable Viability Dye eFluor 780 and incubate 30 min at 4°C. Keep extra cells for other compensation single staining.
Critical: Surface marker staining should be performed here with Live/Dead cell staining before fixation as fixatives can cause antigen epitope structures to be altered, which might render the antibodies unable to bind to their targets. This effect depends on the clone of antibody you're using. The antibodies we used are compatible with fixation and the surface markers staining can be performed with intracellular cytokines staining after fixation. Check this website (https://www.biolegend.com/en-us/fixation[href=https://www.biolegend.com/en-us/fixation]) or consult the literature to confirm whether the antibodies you used are compatible with fixation.

Wash twice by adding 300 μL of FACS buffer, centrifuge at 400 × g for 5 min at 4°C and discard the supernatant.
Fixation and permeabilization
Resuspend cells in 300 μL Fixation/permeabilization solution per 1 million cells. Mix well to dissociate the cell pellet and prevent cross-linking of individual cells.
Fix for 30 min at 4°C.
Immunostaining
Wash twice by adding 300 μL of 1× Perm/Wash solution, centrifuge at 400 × g for 5 min at 4°C and discard the supernatant.
During the spin, prepare multiple staining antibody solution as shown in Table 13[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl13] and single staining solution.
table:files/protocols_protocol_936_13.csv
Resuspend the cell pellet in the well for multiple staining with 100 μL of antibody mix solution shown in Table 13[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl13]. Resuspend the cell pellets in the wells for single staining with 100 μL of respective single staining solution. Resuspend the cell pellet in the well for no staining and Fixable Viability Dye staining with 100 μL of 1× Perm/Wash solution. Incubate for 30 min at 4°C.
Wash twice by adding 300 μL of 1× Perm/Wash solution, centrifuge at 400 × g for 5 min at 4°C and discard the supernatant.
Resuspend the cell pellet in 300 μL of FACS buffer. Passage the cell suspension through the 40 μm cell strainer on top of the 5 mL Falcon® tube before analysis with Fortessa 405/488/561/640 (BD Biosciences) flow cytometer.
See Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5] for the gating strategy of cytokines analysis in CD4+ T cell with Flowjo software.
Alternatives: Splenocytes or OneComp eBeads™ (01-1111-42, Invitrogen) can be used for compensation. If OneComp eBeads™ are used, a mouse, rat or hamster origin antibody with APC-Cy7 labeling should be used for compensation of Fixable Viability Dye eFluor 780.
Critical: Always keep the plate on ice during the staining procedure and use a centrifuge set at 4°C.

Evaluate the level of p-STAT5 in differentiated CD4+ T cells by flow cytometry
Timing: 4–4.5 h
This step contains information on fixation, permeabilization, antibody staining for phosphorylated STAT5 in differentiated CD4+ T cells by flow cytometry.
Live/Dead cell staining
Take 1 × 106 cells and fix them with 4% PFA for 10 min on ice to generate a positive cell control for dead cells staining.
Wash twice by adding 300 μL of FACS buffer, centrifuge at 400 × g for 5 min at 4°C and discard the supernatant.
Mix fixed cells with 1 × 106 unfixed cells and use this sample as a single-stained cell compensation control for the Fixable Viability Dye.
Transfer 1 × 106 cells to each labeled 1.5 mL centrifuge tube and centrifuge the sample at 400 × g for 5 min at 4°C. Discard the supernatant completely.
Note: To avoid excessive cell loss, we used 1.5 mL centrifuge tube instead of 96-well round bottom plate in this section.
During the spin, prepare Live/Dead Fixable Viability Dye eFluor 780 staining solution by diluting 1 μL of original solution with 2 mL of 1×PBS (pH 7.4).
Note: During the following steps, cells have to be protected from light.
Resuspend the cell pellet in the tube for multiple staining and single staining compensation control for the Fixable Viability Dye with 100 μL of diluted Live/Dead Fixable Viability Dye eFluor 780. Resuspend the cell pellets in other tubes with 1×PBS (pH 7.4) and incubate 30 min at 4°C.
Wash twice by adding 300 μL of FACS buffer, centrifuge at 400 × g for 5 min at 4°C and discard the supernatant.
Fixation
Resuspend cells in 100 μL 4% formaldehyde per 1 million cells. Mix well to dissociate the cell pellet and prevent cross-linking of individual cells.

Fix for 30 min at 4°C.
Note: Due to the nature of fixatives, they can cause antigen epitope structures to be altered, which might render the antibodies unable to bind to their targets. Surface marker staining before fixation is suggested. This effect depends on the clone of antibody you're using. The antibodies we used are compatible with fixation and the surface markers staining can be performed with intracellular cytokines staining after fixation. Check this website (https://www.biolegend.com/en-us/fixation[href=https://www.biolegend.com/en-us/fixation]) or consult the literature to confirm whether the antibodies you used are compatible with fixation.
Permeabilization
Permeabilize cells by slowly adding ice-cold 100% methanol to pre-chilled cells while gently vortexing to a final concentration of 90% methanol.
Permeabilize for 45 min on ice.
Pause point: Proceed with immunostaining or store cells at −20°C in 90% methanol.
Immunostaining
Wash twice by adding 300 μL of FACS buffer, centrifuge at 400 × g for 5 min at 4°C and discard the supernatant.
During the spin, prepare multiple staining antibody solution as shown in Table 14[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl14] and single staining solution.
table:files/protocols_protocol_936_14.csv
Resuspend the cell pellet in the well for multiple staining with 100 μL of antibody mix solution. Resuspend the cell pellets in the wells for single staining with 100 μL of respective single staining solution. Resuspend the cell pellet in the well for no staining and Fixable Viability Dye staining with 100 μL of FACS buffer. Incubate for 30 min at 4°C.
Wash twice by adding 300 μL of FACS buffer, centrifuge at 400 × g for 5 min at 4°C and discard the supernatant.
Resuspend the cell pellet in 300 μL of FACS buffer. Passage the cell suspension through the 40 μm cell strainer on top of the 5 mL Falcon® tube before analysis with Fortessa 405/488/561/640 (BD Biosciences) flow cytometer.

See Figure 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6] for the gating strategy of p-STAT5 analysis in CD4+ T cell with Flowjo software.
Alternatives: Splenocytes or OneComp eBeads™ (01-1111-42, Invitrogen) can be used for compensation. If OneComp eBeads™ are used, a mouse, rat or hamster origin antibody with APC-Cy7 labeling should be used for compensation of Fixable Viability Dye eFluor 780.
Critical: Always keep the plate on ice during the staining procedure and use a centrifuge set at 4°C.
